page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 148: Line 148:
On the night of the 10 July, gunmen [[Arab Gas Pipeline|blew up]] an Egyptian [[natural gas]] pipeline to Israel and Jordan in the town of [[El-Arish]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Sweilam |first=Ashraf |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43719969/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Gunmen blow up Egyptian gas pipeline to Israel - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref> This is the fourth time this has occurred this year and the second time in less than a week
On the night of the 10 July, gunmen [[Arab Gas Pipeline|blew up]] an Egyptian [[natural gas]] pipeline to Israel and Jordan in the town of [[El-Arish]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Sweilam |first=Ashraf |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43719969/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Gunmen blow up Egyptian gas pipeline to Israel - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref> This is the fourth time this has occurred this year and the second time in less than a week
â
On the 11 July, Prime Minister Essam Sharaf made a televised statement reassuring protesters that the government would respond to public demands and also included a timeline in which these demands would be met. The changes included a new cabinet to be formed within one week and a change in provincial governors before the end of the month. The protesters responded with calls for a million-man march the following day and continuation of their sit-in in Tahrir Square. The Muslim Brotherhood responded that they will not participate in the sit-in. The next morning the SCAF issued a statement<ref>{{cite web|title=Military Council in Egypt: We Support The People's Demands; We Will Not Submit to Protestor Violence|url=http://www.thememriblog.org/blog_personal/en/39250.htm|publisher=http://www.thememriblog.org/|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref>, which was perceived as aggressive.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mass protests continue against Egyptian regime|url=http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_63395.shtml|accessdate=17 July 2011|newspaper=http://axisoflogic.com/|date=16 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On the 11 July, Prime Minister Essam Sharaf made a televised statement reassuring protesters that the government would respond to public demands and also included a timeline in which these demands would be met. The changes included a new cabinet to be formed within one week and a change in provincial governors before the end of the month. The protesters responded with calls for a million-man march the following day and continuation of their sit-in in Tahrir Square. The Muslim Brotherhood responded that they will not participate in the sit-in. The next morning the SCAF issued a statement<ref>http://www.thememriblog.org/blog_personal/en/39250.htm</ref>, which was perceived as aggressive.<ref>http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_63395.shtml</ref>
â
On the 13 July, state television reported that Egypt's government had met a key demand of protesters by firing nearly 700 top police officers in order to cleanse the discredited and widely unpopular force.<ref>{{cite web|title=State TV: Egypt fires nearly 700 senior officers as part of cleansing police force|url=http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html|publisher=http://www.newser.com/|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref> It was also reported that 37 of the dismissed officers face charges of killing protesters. Among those dismissed were 505 major-generals, including 10 of the interior minister's top assistants, 82 colonels and 82 brigadiers.<ref>{{cite web|title=State TV: Egypt fires nearly 700 senior officers as part of cleansing police force|url=http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html|publisher=http://www.newser.com/|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On the 13 July, state television reported that Egypt's government had met a key demand of protesters by firing nearly 700 top police officers in order to cleanse the discredited and widely unpopular force.<ref>http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html</ref> It was also reported that 37 of the dismissed officers face charges of killing protesters. Among those dismissed were 505 major-generals, including 10 of the interior minister's top assistants, 82 colonels and 82 brigadiers.<ref>http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html</ref>
â
On the 14 July, former President [[Hosni Mubarak]] told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the 18-day uprising that forced him to resign in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers but judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html|publisher=http://www.voanews.com/|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref> Mubarak says he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against people taking part in the protests against his three-decade autocratic rule. He denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html|publisher=http://www.voanews.com/|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On the 14 July, former President [[Hosni Mubarak]] told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the 18-day uprising that forced him to resign in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers but judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref>http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html</ref> Mubarak says he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against people taking part in the protests against his three-decade autocratic rule. He denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref>http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html</ref>
â
On the 16 July, a member of Egypt's ruling military council briefly visited a protest camp in a central Cairo square, but left after protesters, some holding up shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi had come to Tahrir Square to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago, but was forced to cut short his visit because of the heckling. El-Mahdi later told state TV that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|accessdate=17 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/|date=16 July 2011}}</ref> In the latest move to calm rising public anger, Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] accepted the resignation of foreign minister Mohammed el-Orabi. Sharaf also appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist, and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>{{cite news|title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|accessdate=17 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/|date=16 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On the 16 July, a member of Egypt's ruling military council briefly visited a protest camp in a central Cairo square, but left after protesters, some holding up shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi had come to Tahrir Square to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago, but was forced to cut short his visit because of the heckling. El-Mahdi later told state TV that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/</ref> In the latest move to calm rising public anger, Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] accepted the resignation of foreign minister Mohammed el-Orabi. Sharaf also appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist, and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|accessdate=17 July 2011</ref>
â
On the 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State TV dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were relative newcomers which was seen as a way to avoid further criticism by the protesters. Even after the Cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters in the square said they have no intention of calling off their sit-in, which had been in place for more than a week.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt PM names new ministers in face of protests Read more: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL#ixzz1SP06eRv9|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL|accessdate=17 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.sfgate.com/}}</ref> One of the prominent members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
+
On the 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State TV dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were relative newcomers which was seen as a way to avoid further criticism by the protesters. Even after the Cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters in the square said they have no intention of calling off their sit-in, which had been in place for more than a week.<ref>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL</ref> One of the prominent members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
â
Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Finance Minister Samir Radwan (the reason for his resignation was due to the fact that his new budget was deemed by many protestors to be too conservative in dealing with the poverty which had been one of the main catalysts of the uprising) and the foreign minister, who was replaced by the former ambassador to Saudia Arabia, Mohammed Kamel Omar. Radwan's position was taken by prominent economist Hazem el-Biblawi, who had also been appointed deputy prime minister. There were also changes in the ministries of transport, military production, higher education, communication, agriculture, health, religious endowments, local development, trade and industry and civil aviation, with ministers being replaced.
+
Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Finance Minister Samir Radwan (the reason for his resignation was due to the fact that his new budget was deemed by many protestors to be too conservative in dealing with the poverty which had been one of the main catalysts of the uprising) and the foreign minister, who was replaced by the former ambassador to Saudia Arabia, Mohammed Kamel Omar. Radwan's position was taken by prominent economist Hazem el-Biblawi, who had also been appointed deputy prime minister. There were also changes in the ministries of transport, military production, higher education, communication, agriculture, health, religious endowments, local development, trade and industry and civil aviation, with ministers being replaced<ref>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL</ref>.
â
<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt PM names new ministers in face of protests Read more: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL#ixzz1SP06eRv9|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL|accessdate=17 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.sfgate.com/}}</ref>
